quoteFirst: On a platform just outside are numerous arms and signals--one arm is lowered; then another. The Charing-Cross portion of the mail is in now. It is
quoteLast: --no doubt the "official" time for starting--and with a shriek we pass from the brilliant station to the darkness of the river.
title:
Little Folks (December 1884)
A Magazine for the Young
author: Various

quoteFirst: So the affairs of the world stood when the sun went down on the 15th of July. On the meridian of Aeria it set at nine minutes to eight; at
quoteLast: , according to the calculations made by the Martian and verified by the Aerian astronomers, the herald of Fate would approach within the range of terrestrial vision.
title: Olga Romanoff
author: Griffith, George Chetwynd, 1857-1906; Jane, Fred T. (Frederick Thomas), 1865-1916 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Sprite and the little Forest Fay, and before
quoteLast: every one was there. Well, by and by it came time to cut the big birthday cake in which was hidden a little gold ring, and of course everyone hoped he would find it in his piece of cake.
title: Little Jack Rabbit and Uncle John Hare
author: Cory, David, 1872-1966; Barbour, Harold S., 1889-1961 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: In the middle of the Sound are a number of islands of various sizes. The depth of water in the middle of the Sound, and even close home to some parts of its shore, is from
quoteLast: ty fathoms, and perhaps more. The harbours, and anchoring-places within its circuit, are numerous; but we had no time to survey them.
title: A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels, Volume 16
author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteFirst: Seems to grow “small by degrees and beautifully less,” his diameter at the close of the month being only 4.8″. He sets at 9:25 on the evening of the 1st; at 8:51 p. m. on the 15th, and at
quoteLast: on the 30th. On the 24th, at 10:29 a. m. he is only 10′ south of the moon.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, July 1884, No. 10
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: In the middle of the sound are a number of islands of various sizes; but the chart or sketch of the sound here annexed, though it has no pretensions to accuracy, will, with all its imperfections, convey a better idea of these islands, and of the figure, and the extent of the sound, than any written description. The depth of water in the middle of the sound, and even close home to some parts of its shore, is from
quoteLast: ty fathoms, and perhaps more. The harbours and anchoring-places within its circuit are numerous; but we had no time to survey them. The cove in which our ships lay is on the east side of the sound, and on the east side of the largest of the islands.
title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World. Vol. VI. Being the Second of the Third Voyage
author: Cook, James, 1728-1779

quoteLast: we alighted in a sandy plain absolutely without herbage, covered with loose stones, a quarter of a mile due north of the well, which is in the narrow gorge, forming the southern outlet of this small plain. Though we had travelled thirteen hours and a quarther this day, it was but at a slow pace, our camels being famished, as well as tired, and lamed likewise by the sharp stones with which the ground in all places was covered.
title:
Travels to Discover the Source of the Nile, Volume 4 (of 5)
In the years 1768, 1769, 1770, 1771, 1772 and 1773
author: Bruce, James, 1730-1794
